title-group.article-title: Tracking Anti-Teleology: Is There an "End" in Sight?

ref.mixed-citation: See the bibliography given in P. Gifford and J. Gratton (eds.), Subject Matters: Subject and Self in French Literature from Descartes to the Present (Amsterdam: Rodopi, 1999).
See in particular Soi-même comme un autre (Paris: Seuil, 1990) and my chapter "The Res- onance of Ricceur" in Subject Matters, 200-25.

"Subject" implies an instance of conscious control subjecting (subjugere) the energies of the psyche to unifying direction from above; whereas "sub-jet" connotes an undifferentiated upwelling from below of pre-rational psychic energies.
See Jean-Louis Lebrave, "La critique génétique: une discipline nouvelle ou un avatar de la philologie?" Genesis 1 (1992): 33-72.
Almuth Grésillon, Eléments de critique génétique. Lire les manuscrits modernes (Paris: P.U.F., 1994), 137.

"Ovide chez les Scythes": Un "beau sujet." Etude génétique d'un manuscrit inédit de Paul Valéry par le groupe "Paul Valéry" de 1Ί.Τ.Ε.Μ. (C.N.R.S.). Textes réunis par Huguette Laurent! (Centre d'Etudes du XXe siècle—études valéryennes, Université Paul Valéry, Montpellier, 1997).
Robert Pickering, "Ovide en face à face," in "Ovide chez les Scythes": Un "beau sujet," 45.
Critique génétique. Cahier n° I, "Pas" (Paris: L'Harmattan, 1991).

See my treatment of this same motif in "La Jeune Parque et les pas de l'écriture," 13-35, in A. Goulet, with P. Gifford (eds.), Voix, traces, avènement. L'Ecriture et son sujet. Colloque de Cerisy-La-Salle (Presses Universitaires de Caen, 1999).
Paul Valéry, Œuvres, 2 vols., édition établie et annotée par Jean Hytier (Paris: Gallimard, Bibliothèque de la Pléiade, 1957, 1960), I, 1339.
Almuth Grésillon distinguishes usefully, for instance, between "l'écriture à programme" and "l'écriture à processus" (Eléments de critique génétique 102).

See Jiirgen Moltmann, The Coming of God (London: SCM Press, 1996). Judaic-Christian particularity is seen to involve a radical recasting of human thinking about time as a one- way "negentropic" flow, horizontally finalized by human absolutes. Within this time, it envisages a recreative irruption of the future of all time, all history—of an "endtime" that is the presence of "him who is and who was and who is to come" (Rev. 1,4 ). Rationalist- idealist finalism yields here to a—very radical—form of "endtime" teleology known as eschalology, conceived—like genetics—in terms of event and advent (cf. A. Grésillon 109).
Cahiers, fac-similé des 261 cahiers manuscrits, en 29 vols. (Paris: C.N.R.S., 1957-1961), XXIV, 595.
Gnosis is centrally envisaged here as an unachieved, mimetic emulation of Divinity: "Ye shall be as gods," says the seducing Serpent...

Cf. "Aurore" (Charmes): "Etre, universelle oreille/Toute l'âme s'appareille/A l'extrême du désir"; also the burlesque "envoi" of "Ebauche": "—Cette soif qui te fit géant/Jusqu'à l'Etre exalte l'étrange/Toute-Puissance du néant."
